conversation.content: [belly laugh] You actually kept that wrench from your first job? That's incredible.
Oh man, yeah, I mean, it's probably worth like three dollars now but... I don't know, it's got all these scratches and dents from when I didn't know what I was doing.
How long have you been doing construction now?
Uhh, coming up on seventeen years next month. Started when I was nineteen, right out of high school, thought it'd be temporary but, well, here I am still swinging hammers.
[cheerful] That's amazing! You must have built hundreds of things by now.

Hundreds, yeah, probably more like thousands if you count all the little stuffâ€”decks, additions, renovations. Though honestly, I, uh, I stopped counting after a while because it all kind of blurs together.
Do you remember your first big project?
Mmm, yeah, this massive house out in Westfield. I was so nervous I threw up in the porta-potty that first morning. The foreman, he just laughed and said welcome to the real world, kid.
That must have been overwhelming.
Overwhelming is, er, putting it mildly. I mean, I went home every night that first week wondering if I'd made a huge mistake, you know? My hands were raw, my back was killing me.
But you stuck with it.
Well, yeah, I mean, what else was I gonna do? College wasn't happening, and the money was decent, plus my dad would've never let me hear the end of it if I'd quit.
[monotone] My dad wanted me to go into trades too.
[upset] Yeah? And let me guess, you went to college instead, got some nice clean office job where the biggest hazard is a paper cut, right? That's how it always goes.
[speeding up] No, no, that's not what I meant at all. I really admire what you do.
[short pause] Sorry, that was... I get defensive sometimes. People look at you different when your hands are dirty, you know? Like you're somehow less than.
I never thought that. Ever.
[bitter] Mmm, well, most people do, whether they admit it or not. Oh, he's just a construction worker, he must not be that bright, must not have had other options, all that garbage.
[enunciating every word] You are building the world that everyone else just lives in.
[short pause] Damn. I, uh... nobody's ever put it like that before. That's actually... yeah. Thank you. I'm gonna remember that one for a while, I think.
